Paper(s): Weedman+1982 ; Subramanian+1984 ; Wier+1991 ; Duncan+1991 ; Steidel+1991 ; Bonnet+1993 ; Fischer+1994 ; Mellier+1994 ; Patnaik+1996 ; Dolan+1996 ; Small+1997 ; Green+2002
Notes: No X-ray evidence for a foreground lensing cluster found by Green+2002 and no lens identified; X-ray continua are found to be incompatible as are the optical to X-ray flux ratios; the optical spectral similarities remains a mystery. Coordinates from Simbad.

Selection Method: Slitless Spectroscopic Survey / CCD spectra and imaging
Notes: Spectra have striking similarities but no evidence for a lensing cluster of galaxy even in HST imaging. Coordinates from Simbad.
Coordinates from Simbad. Redshifts pulled from Hudson+2006.

Possible QSO-AGN pair at similar redshifts but note the redshift differences as these might be further away than originally thought ; Hu+1987 call into question interepretation and conclude that companion is likely just an ionized gas cloud. Coordinates come from Simbad.
Using the same coordinates because secondary coordinates not specified. Coordinates come from Simbad.
Distinct BLR emitting regions can be plausibly explained via a dual AGN scenario. Not conclusive at this point. Redshift adopted from Simbad.
Separation of optical sources AB_opt and C is 4.8 arcsec but separation of radio sources is roughly 5.9 arcsec. Coordinates come from Simbad (and originally from SDSS).

Halpern+1988 test binary hypothesis based on offset broad emission line but no firm conclusion made. Other papers conclude that bianry hypothesis can be ruled out. Coordinates from Simbad. Redshift from Ned agrees with Simbad to 3 decimal points.
Proposed as a SMBH binary with separation ~0.1pc.
Redshifts from Crampton+1988 but Dinshaw+1994 quote slightly different redshifts. Coordinates from simbad.
Dual candidate and see earlier papers by Petrosian+1980 Osterbrock+1983 and Kollatschny+1984 about optical spectroscopy.

Despite the original suspicion that this was a gravitational lens candidate Mthur+2003 argue against the lens interpretation and find that the X-ray properties of the sources are incompatible with one another and that the X-ray emission from the potential foreground cluster is unlikely to be the long soughtafter foreground lens ; Aldrcroft confirm many of Mathur's findings but argues that the lens interpretation cannot be completely ruled out. Coordinates from simbad.

Confirmation Method: Plate Imaging / Spectroscopic Follow-up / HST Imaging
Notes: Considered a lens candidate by Hewett+89 but Faure+2003 argue based on VLT and HST data that the system is unlikely to be a lens but rather is a true binary ; note that 1429-008 from Hewett+89 is 1429-0053 from Faure+2003. Coordinates come from Simbad and are not unique (had to be used for both components). Coordinates originally from Gaia.
Coordinates come from Simbad; unique coordinates not available apparently. Coordinates come from Gaia DR2.
Coordinates come from simbad; no separation shown in the two papers. One if not two hard X-ray sources located in the nuclear regions of this ULIRG.

Selection Method: Optical Light Curve Variability / Jet Precession
Notes: Coordinates come from Simbad
Considered a good candidate for a lens system but the binary hypothesis cannot be ruled out by Hewett+ ; Lehar+2000 identified the lens galaxy in HST imaging

Maoz+1992 reported that the quasar was resolved into three images but Maoz+1992b report that follow-up HST images do not show such a third image and therefore the third image was likely an artifact. Thus the binary hypothesis has not yet been ruled out. I think Gaia resolves only a single source (based on Simbad listing).

Redshifts adopted from Green+2004 ; Lopez+ point out that the lens interpreation cannot yet be ruled out. Green+2004 show via VLA imaging that B is a radio loud BAL QSO but A is radio quiet ; by contrast A is brighter in the optical and thus the broadband flux ratios would be in disagreement and time delays are unlikely to account for this discrepancy. This is very likely a true binary pair. Coordinates from Simbad.
Coordinates from Simbad.

Selection Method: Optical Spectroscopy / Double-peaked Optical Emission lines
Notes: Coordinates from Simbad

Selection Method: Optical Spectroscopy / Double-peaked Optical Emission lines
Notes: Coordinates and redshift from Simbad
Coordinates from Simbad. ICRF designation in Simbad.
Likely lens but a binary hypothesis could not be ruled out. Coordinates from simbad
Dark lens hypothesis argued to be the best explanation by Hawkins+1997 but binary interpretation cannot be ruled out. Coordinates taken from Simbad.
Coordinates from Simbad and closrly agree with NED

DOI(s): Coordinates from Simbad and originallu from Gaia.

Notes: Few details are provided by Boyle+1999 but it is considered a lens candidate though certainly the binary interpretation cannot be ruled out; the spectra look similar although B has a huge Mg II absorption trough and A does not

Confirmation Method: Optical Spectroscopy / Infrared Imaging / Radio Imaging
Notes: Lens hypthesis ruled out based on extreme differences between the optical flux ratio and radio flux ratio of the two sources ; Source A is a quasar and source B is a Seyfert 1. Coordinates from Simbad

Confirmation Method: Optical Imaging / Infrared Imaging / Optical Spectroscopy
Notes: Spectral dissimilarities and broadband flux ratios as well as lack of lens argue in favor of binary hypothesis
Very likely to be a lens rather than a binary ; redshifts correspond to the redshift of component A. Coordinates from Gregg+ and from Simbad
Coordinates from Simbad

While Muñoz+ concludes that this is very likely a lens system but could not conclusively rule out the binary hypothesis a later paper by Popvic does conclude it is a genuine pair based on spectroscopic observations. Coordinates are unique and come from Simbad (which labels this as a lensed QSO system). Gaia has only one source listed on Simbad.
Considered a good lens candidate but without the detection of a foreground lens candidate the binary hypothesis cannot be ruled out. Coordinates from Simbad.
Coordinates are not unique and are drawn from Simbad
Component B is a FeLoBAL quasar ; the striking differences in the spectra and short time delay rule out a lens interpretation. Coordinates from Gregg+2002

Binary interpretation is favored for this system due to a lack of a lens ; dissimilarities in the N V and C IV emission line profiles; and the line of sight velocity difference. Coordinates not unique and come from Simbad.
Angular separation is based on optical nuclei and pulled from Komossa+'s introduction; Need to find accurate X-ray positions for sources
VLBI phase reference imaging suggests orbital motion on order of year; Sudou+ claim possible presence of binary in addition to jet precession to explain observations
Coordinates come from Simbad; not listed in Heidt's paper. Coordinates are not unique; only coordinates for the primary are available.
Coordinates for 3C 294 come from McCaryh+94 after conversion to ICRS in paper; VLA imaging at 6cm gives coordinates

Need to double check the redshift for this system; Note that Arp 299 is mistakenly claimed to comprise IC 694 and NGC 3690 but IC 694 is a lenticular galaxy not associated with the two primary merging galaxies; our naming convention takes this into account. I quote the XMM 2-10keV X-ray coordinates of the AGNs from Ballo+ to avoid confusion with multiple APG namings but these coordinates are likely not the same exact coordinate as the Chandra source (which was not listed). Separation not based on X-ray coordinates but on work by Heckman.
Coordinates correspond to the X-ray positions but the quoted separation is for the optical nuclei
Coordinates from Simbad. Also known as ICRF J040549.2+380332.
Coordinates from Simbad

Confirmation Method: Double-Peaked Spectroscopic Emission Lines / VLBA Imaging
Notes: Double-peaked emission lines considered as two separate NLRs and VLBA imaging reveals two sources separted via roughly 2.5 mas. Coordinates taken from Simbad. ICRF designation on Simbad.
This is a system of radio tailed galaxies akin to 3C 75 and therefore is very likely to be hosting a pair of radio loud AGNs

Confirmation Method: Optical Imaging / NIR Imaging / Optical Spectroscopy

Notes: This is in Hennawi's 2006 catalog
Coordinates pulled from Simbad

Komossa+ argues that J0927 constitutes a likely recoil candidate while Shields+ argues that the superposition hypothesis deserves more attention and Bogdanović+ argues that the system is more likely a binary SMBH system
Angular separation comes from separation of the Chandra sources;
Individual redshifts are taken from Table 1 in Comerford+2009a and the coordinates are taken from Simbad
Coordinates from the COSMOS naming convention
Coordinates come from Simbad. NOTE: The RA listed for AM1211-465SW in Jimémenz-Bailón+ is incorrect (off by an arcmin).
